articles.headline: Two Who Got 2013 Right See 2014 as Much the Same
articles.snippet: Widespread optimism about the stock market, the economy, and corporate profits, but pessimism when it comes to the bond market.
articles.abstract: Widespread optimism about the stock market, the economy, and corporate profits, but pessimism when it comes to the bond market.
articles.lead_paragraph: After a banner year for stocks and a rocky one for bonds, market forecasters are remarkably consistent in their forecasts for 2014: more of the same.

articles.headline: Unemployed in Europe Stymied by Lack of Technology Skills
articles.snippet: Thousands of jobs are languishing unfilled as many in the work force find that their skills are ill suited for posts in information technology.
articles.abstract: Thousands of jobs are languishing unfilled as many in the work force find that their skills are ill suited for posts in information technology.
articles.lead_paragraph: DUBLIN — Week after week, newspapers issue a stream of hopeful headlines: Microsoft, PayPal, Fujitsu and scores of other companies are expanding their investments in Ireland, creating thousands of jobs as unemployment hovers near record highs.

articles.headline: Access to Abortion Falling as States Pass Restrictions
articles.snippet: A surge in anti-abortion measures in more than half the states has made it far more difficult in many regions to obtain the procedure.
articles.abstract: A surge in anti-abortion measures in more than half the states has made it far more difficult in many regions to obtain the procedure.
articles.lead_paragraph: A three-year surge in anti-abortion measures in more than half the states has altered the landscape for abortion access, with supporters and opponents agreeing that the new restrictions are shutting some clinics, threatening others and making it far more difficult in many regions to obtain the procedure.

articles.headline: A Lexicon of Instant Argot
articles.snippet: Urban Dictionary has become a real-time archive for new and slang terms, particularly those that have risen because of social media and the web.
articles.abstract: Urban Dictionary has become a real-time archive for new and slang terms, particularly those that have risen because of social media and the web.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Millions watched and gossiped online as Miley Cyrus “twerked” on stage at MTV’s video music awards in late 2013. Then, they rushed to Urban Dictionary to figure out what that was — making “twerk” one of the most-searched terms on the site all year.

articles.headline: Make a Resolution to Budget? Here Are Some Apps to Help
articles.snippet: Several applications are available to help consumers set up a budget and track their income and expenditures.
articles.abstract: Several applications are available to help consumers set up a budget and track their income and expenditures.
articles.lead_paragraph: There’s something brilliant, but also insidious, about services like Amazon Prime, where you don’t have to reach for your credit card to pay. Spending is painless.

articles.headline: A Cult Motorcycle From India Takes On the World
articles.snippet: With models like the Bullet, an Indian-made avatar of an old British brand, Royal Enfield is making waves even as the competition for midsize bikes is heating up.
articles.abstract: With models like the Bullet, an Indian-made avatar of an old British brand, Royal Enfield is making waves even as the competition for midsize bikes is heating up.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI, India — The Royal Enfield Bullet, often described as the oldest continuously produced motorcycle in the world, is a cult product for enthusiasts who love it for its vintage feel as much as for the thrum of its engine.

articles.headline: Mystery in Hezbollah Operative’s Life and Death
articles.snippet: The assassination of Hassane Laqees, Hezbollah’s master technician and logistics expert, has exposed a convulsing region’s tangled and shifting alliances and enmities.
articles.abstract: The assassination of Hassane Laqees, Hezbollah’s master technician and logistics expert, has exposed a convulsing region’s tangled and shifting alliances and enmities.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — As a little girl, Noor did not know exactly what her father, Hassane Laqees, did for Hezbollah, but even then, she knew she might lose him early. During his long absences, she recalled recently, she would gaze at a photo of him lying asleep and imagine that she was seeing his corpse.

articles.headline: Solar Power Craze on Wall St. Propels Start-Up
articles.snippet: The rise of SolarCity, a provider of rooftop solar systems, is either a sign that solar power is finally having its day or that yet another mania has gripped the markets.
articles.abstract: The rise of SolarCity, a provider of rooftop solar systems, is either a sign that solar power is finally having its day or that yet another mania has gripped the markets.
articles.lead_paragraph: The first inklings of the idea came to Elon Musk and a cousin in an R.V. heading to the Burning Man festival in 2004.
articles.byline: By Diane Cardwell and Julie Creswell

articles.headline: Tangled Role in G.O.P. War Over Tea Party
articles.snippet: The activities of Steven C. LaTourette, an ex-congressman who defends centrist Republicans from Tea Party challengers, have raised questions about whether he is profiting from his role and violating lobbying rules.
articles.abstract: The activities of Steven C. LaTourette, an ex-congressman who defends centrist Republicans from Tea Party challengers, have raised questions about whether he is profiting from his role and violating lobbying rules.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the year since he stepped down from Congress, Steven C. LaTourette, a Republican from Ohio, has emerged as one of the top generals in the establishment Republicans’ war against the Tea Party.

articles.headline: U.S. Is Facing Hard Choices in South Sudan
articles.snippet: With no plans for American military intervention, the United States is frantically brokering peace talks between the warring factions while trying to fortify a United Nations peacekeeping force.
articles.abstract: With no plans for American military intervention, the United States is frantically brokering peace talks between the warring factions while trying to fortify a United Nations peacekeeping force.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — South Sudan is in many ways an American creation, carved out of war-torn Sudan in a referendum largely orchestrated by the United States, its fragile institutions nurtured with billions of dollars in American aid. But a murky, vicious conflict there has left the Obama administration scrambling to prevent the unraveling of a major American achievement in Africa.

articles.headline: A Roadblock to Brawny Bank Reform
articles.snippet: The calendar has turned, but tougher capital rules for the banking industry are still awaiting approval.
articles.abstract: The calendar has turned, but tougher capital rules for the banking industry are still awaiting approval.
articles.lead_paragraph: Regulators made some real progress last year attacking the risks of too-big-to-fail banks. The Volcker Rule and other Dodd-Frank reforms were completed, and, perhaps even more important, three big regulators devised a proposal for tougher capital rules intended to ensure that banks would never require a government bailout when their risky bets went bad.

articles.headline: But It Doesn’t Look Like a Marriott
articles.snippet: To lure a younger crowd, Marriott International is making a turn toward flash, partly by offering new hotel brands.
articles.abstract: To lure a younger crowd, Marriott International is making a turn toward flash, partly by offering new hotel brands.
articles.lead_paragraph: J.W. Marriott Jr., the 81-year-old chairman of Marriott International, flew to London in September to inspect his company’s new jewel: Edition, a sumptuous boutique hotel intended to anchor a new 100-city chain — the next W, if Marriott has its way. But Mr. Marriott did not stay overnight at the London Edition, as the new property is known, with its laser-lighted nightclub and guest-room paintings of women wearing toilet-paper turbans. He bedded down at Grosvenor House, one of the company’s more traditional luxury hotels.

articles.headline: Management Be Nimble
articles.snippet: How to keep your company as fresh as a start-up? In hundreds of interviews, executives shared the paths they took to energize their corporate cultures.
articles.abstract: How to keep your company as fresh as a start-up? In hundreds of interviews, executives shared the paths they took to energize their corporate cultures.
articles.lead_paragraph: “We aspire to be the largest small company in our space.”

articles.headline: Banished for Questioning the Gospel of Guns
articles.snippet: A longtime columnist for a gun magazine questioned when the regulation of guns became infringement of the right to bear arms. He was quickly fired, squelching any debate.
articles.abstract: A longtime columnist for a gun magazine questioned when the regulation of guns became infringement of the right to bear arms. He was quickly fired, squelching any debate.
articles.lead_paragraph: BARRY, Ill. — The byline of Dick Metcalf, one of the country’s pre-eminent gun journalists, has gone missing. It has been removed from Guns & Ammo magazine, where his widely-read column once ran on the back page. He no longer stars on a popular television show about firearms. Gun companies have stopped flying him around the world and sending him the latest weapons to review.

articles.headline: 50 Years Later, War on Poverty Is a Mixed Bag
articles.snippet: The debate over the government’s role in creating opportunity and ending deprivation has flared anew, with inequality as acute as it was in the Roaring Twenties and the ranks of the poor and near-poor at record highs.
articles.abstract: The debate over the government’s role in creating opportunity and ending deprivation has flared anew, with inequality as acute as it was in the Roaring Twenties and the ranks of the poor and near-poor at record highs.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — To many Americans, the war on poverty declared 50 years ago by President Lyndon B. Johnson has largely failed. The poverty rate has fallen only to 15 percent from 19 percent in two generations, and 46 million Americans live in households where the government considers their income scarcely adequate.

articles.headline: A Lonely Quest for Facts on Genetically Modified Crops
articles.snippet: When a bill to ban genetically engineered crops on the island of Hawaii was introduced, doubts nagged at Greggor Ilagan, a councilman, about what the risks were, if any, of the crops.
articles.abstract: When a bill to ban genetically engineered crops on the island of Hawaii was introduced, doubts nagged at Greggor Ilagan, a councilman, about what the risks were, if any, of the crops.
articles.lead_paragraph: KONA, Hawaii — From the moment the bill to ban genetically engineered crops on the island of Hawaii was introduced in May 2013, it garnered more vocal support than any the County Council here had ever considered, even the perennially popular bids to decriminalize marijuana.

articles.headline: Power Vacuum in Middle East Lifts Militants
articles.snippet: The bloodshed that has engulfed Iraq, Lebanon and Syria exposes the emergence of a post-American Middle East in which no broker has the will or power to contain the region’s sectarian hatreds.
articles.abstract: The bloodshed that has engulfed Iraq, Lebanon and Syria exposes the emergence of a post-American Middle East in which no broker has the will or power to contain the region’s sectarian hatreds.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The images of recent days have an eerie familiarity, as if the horrors of the past decade were being played back: masked gunmen recapturing the Iraqi cities of Falluja and Ramadi, where so many American soldiers died fighting them. Car bombs exploding amid the elegance of downtown Beirut. The charnel house of Syria’s worsening civil war.
articles.byline: By Ben Hubbard, Robert F. Worth and Michael R. Gordon

articles.headline: NBC Begins Swarm of Ads to Lift ‘Today’ Back to Top
articles.snippet: The NBC morning news program, which has been second to “Good Morning America” for 16 months, will open its offensive with a major promotional campaign.
articles.abstract: The NBC morning news program, which has been second to “Good Morning America” for 16 months, will open its offensive with a major promotional campaign.
articles.lead_paragraph: The “Today” show, so accustomed to winning, has grown impatient with losing.

articles.headline: $1 Billion as Milestone and Omen
articles.snippet: Silicon Valley today is a huge, undulating bubble. But which companies are overvalued and which are not is the $1 billion question.
articles.abstract: Silicon Valley today is a huge, undulating bubble. But which companies are overvalued and which are not is the $1 billion question.
articles.lead_paragraph: Fab.com, an online retailer selling affordable high design, last year seemed as if it could be the next Amazon.
articles.byline: By David Gelles and Claire Cain Miller

articles.headline: Print Starts to Settle Into Its Niches
articles.snippet: At a time when e-book sales seem to be flattening, there is something to be learned from Kevin Kelly’s self-published print catalog, a collection of reviews accrued from a website over the years.
articles.abstract: At a time when e-book sales seem to be flattening, there is something to be learned from Kevin Kelly’s self-published print catalog, a collection of reviews accrued from a website over the years.
articles.lead_paragraph: Kevin Kelly is not a dumb guy — far from it actually. As the founding executive editor of Wired and one of the people who helped build The Well, among the earliest online communities, he has done a good job of seeing what is coming next for decades.

articles.headline: The Muslim Brotherhood, Back in a Fight to Survive
articles.snippet: Members of the Brotherhood, now outlawed and underground, said they were trying to bolster their ranks for a long struggle against Egypt’s military-backed government.
articles.abstract: Members of the Brotherhood, now outlawed and underground, said they were trying to bolster their ranks for a long struggle against Egypt’s military-backed government.
articles.lead_paragraph: FAYOUM, Egypt — They hide in safe houses on the outskirts of this city, talk only fleetingly on cellphones and avoid the cafes where they used to meet. Heavy scarves obscure their identities when they venture out to join protests.

articles.headline: Colorado River Drought Forces a Painful Reckoning for States
articles.snippet: Drought and population growth are driving a reassessment of how the 1,450-mile Colorado, the Southwest’s only major river, can continue to slake the thirst of one of the nation’s fastest-growing regions.
articles.abstract: Drought and population growth are driving a reassessment of how the 1,450-mile Colorado, the Southwest’s only major river, can continue to slake the thirst of one of the nation’s fastest-growing regions.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAKE MEAD, Nev. — The sinuous Colorado River and its slew of man-made reservoirs from the Rockies to southern Arizona are being sapped by 14 years of drought nearly unrivaled in 1,250 years.

articles.headline: Popular Voice in the Capitol? It’s the Pope’s
articles.snippet: Democrats and Republicans alike are seizing on Pope Francis’ messages of economic justice and tolerance.
articles.abstract: Democrats and Republicans alike are seizing on Pope Francis’ messages of economic justice and tolerance.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Shortly before leaving the Capitol for the holiday recess, Senate Democrats gathered behind closed doors to lay out an agenda for 2014. When the majority leader, Harry Reid, exhorted colleagues to “deal with the issue of income inequality,” the talk took a spiritual turn.

articles.headline: Sudan’s Lost Boys Are Drawn Into War at Home
articles.snippet: South Sudan’s Lost Boys, who had escaped the violence in their homeland only to be drawn back, are trying to survive the crisis that is threatening to tear their new country apart.
articles.abstract: South Sudan’s Lost Boys, who had escaped the violence in their homeland only to be drawn back, are trying to survive the crisis that is threatening to tear their new country apart.
articles.lead_paragraph: AWERIAL, South Sudan — When Jacob Atem was just a young boy, his parents were killed during the long war for independence from Sudan, and he found himself among the legions of orphaned children known as the Lost Boys wandering hundreds of miles across this part of Africa.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Kulish and Isma'il Kushkush

articles.headline: JPMorgan Chase Nears a $2 Billion Deal in a Case Tied to Madoff
articles.snippet: The expected deal between federal authorities and JPMorgan Chase would settle a case in which the bank is suspected of ignoring signs of Bernard L. Madoff’s Ponzi scheme.
articles.abstract: The expected deal between federal authorities and JPMorgan Chase would settle a case in which the bank is suspected of ignoring signs of Bernard L. Madoff’s Ponzi scheme.
articles.lead_paragraph: Working through a long list of legal problems, JPMorgan Chase is starting the new year with another steep payout to the government.
articles.byline: By Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Ben Protess

articles.headline: From Petraeus Scandal, an Apostle for Privacy
articles.snippet: Jill Kelley, whose name was released in connection with a scandal that toppled the chief of the Central Intelligence Agency, has filed suit for damages and a formal apology.
articles.abstract: Jill Kelley, whose name was released in connection with a scandal that toppled the chief of the Central Intelligence Agency, has filed suit for damages and a formal apology.
articles.lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — Jill Kelley still glances around for cameras before she leaves her large, six-columned house on Hillsborough Bay, and she rarely goes to the grocery store. Since November 2012, when the government released her name in connection with a scandal that brought down the head of the Central Intelligence Agency, Ms. Kelley has yet to return to her children’s schools, she said, and could not even summon the courage to go to their holiday plays.

articles.headline: ‘Smart TVs’ Are Next Bet for Makers as Sales Languish
articles.snippet: TV makers at the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas will be showing off a range of sets that can connect to the Internet and run apps.
articles.abstract: TV makers at the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas will be showing off a range of sets that can connect to the Internet and run apps.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Big, bright, sharp and sophisticated, television sets have never looked better. But that’s a problem. The TV industry has innovated itself into a corner.
articles.byline: By Brian X. Chen and Nick Wingfield

articles.headline: Justices’ Halt to Gay Marriage Leaves Utah Couples in Limbo
articles.snippet: Acting more than two weeks after a federal judge struck down Utah’s ban on same-sex marriage, the Supreme Court on Monday halted further unions while an appeals court reviews the ruling.
articles.abstract: Acting more than two weeks after a federal judge struck down Utah’s ban on same-sex marriage, the Supreme Court on Monday halted further unions while an appeals court reviews the ruling.
articles.lead_paragraph: SALT LAKE CITY — In a move that cast doubt over the marriages of roughly 1,000 same-sex couples in Utah, the United States Supreme Court on Monday blocked further same-sex marriages there while state officials appeal a decision allowing such unions.
articles.byline: By Jack Healy and Adam Liptak
